intro: Acalypha alopecuroidea lusus glanduligera, commonly known as the woolly acalypha, is a shrub native to tropical regions of Africa. It is characterized by its dense, fuzzy foliage that gives it a soft, woolly appearance. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically greenish-white in color. Its leaves are often covered in fine, glandular hairs, which contribute to its unique texture and appearance. This species is often cultivated for ornamental purposes due to its striking visual appeal.

It is also present in parts of northern Australia and the Pacific Islands. Its distribution is closely linked to its ability to adapt to a variety of environmental conditions in these regions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha alopecuroidea lusus glanduligera was mainly introduced to New Zealand as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and unique appearance. It was first brought to the country in the early 20th century by horticultural enthusiasts and gardeners.
